addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
.

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 July 23 et 24
It may please yo
r
H. to be advertised, that
as yet I have had no answear from
e
Generall
states
, as touching those Articles whiche I deli-
ered unto them: for whiche they pretend,
at
they have not heard from their Principals.
Whiche I doe not thinke will be long, but yet I
see little hope, that they will yeld to any deputies, that shall come into
England,
suche an ample com-
mission, as is required at their handes. In
e
meane season
e Ennemie, by all advertisments,
maketh great preparation of his forces hitherwardes:
and unles we be further succoured, then there is
apparance that we can be on
e soddaine, it is ge-
nerally feared that he will passe
e Wael: wherof the consequence doth putt them heere in some terro
r
.
For if in this time of discontentm
t
between her
Ma
tie
and them, these contreis should be overtaken
w
t
any notable losse, happely
e common people
would deale somw
at
roughly w
t
e principall
causers of these froward courses, that have bin
held w
t
her Ma
tie
. The Generall
states, and likewise
e
Councell
have bin instant
w
t
me, to intreat my
L. Burgh
for a companie
of foote from
e
Brill,
M
r
Borlas
for two compa-
nies, and
S
r
John Conway
for as many, for that we
heare at this p
nt
,
at the Ennemie doth not presse
him. Because I doe not dout, but it is her Ma
ties
pleasure, that in times of necessitie,
e superfluous
companies of
e Cautionarie townes should be spa-
red, I have
written
very earnestly to suche effect as they
requested. My L. Burgh hath already sent worde
that he can not spare an Enseigne, but will fur-
nishe them by squadron of a convenient troope,
and himself conduct them in person. From
Flus-
hing
and
Ostend
I have no answear as yet.
fol.29v
Moreover to
e self same effect, as the Councell of
state hath written of late unto her Ma
tie
I have
bin dealt w
t
all publickly, and very earnestly, to
solicite
e sending backe of those companies, or others
in their place, whiche were drawen by
S
r
John Norris
from hens, and were to be returned
e first of
June. Wherto I have made
e same answear, w
ch
they receaved from yo
r
H. alleaging
e hindrance
of
e
Portugall
service, through their breache of pro-
mise to S
r
John Norris: also their continuall in-
fringing of
e Contract, to serve their present tur-
nes: and
e smalle regard, whiche they have to
content her Ma
tie
in any demaund: in so muche as
her Hig
nes
doth growe very weery of their un-
grateful proceedinges, All this they labor to ex-
cuse, under coulo
r
of being mistaken, and other
weake pretenses. But howsoever it is, the consi-
deration of their owne weaknes, uppon
e Enne-
mies approching, doth put them at this present
in a great perplexitie, Albeit they are muche re-
lieved by this daies newes, That
S
r
Martin
Schincke
hath revictualled
Berke.
Wheruppon they
hope to serve their turnes w
t
his forces. The En-
terprise was done
e 18 of this moneth, w
t
out
any encounter of
e Ennemie: for
at S
r
Martin
Schincke conducted his forces by secret waies and
so soddainly, as he entred
e towne, before the
Ennemie could perceave it. Whiche hath mer-
velously spited
e Marquis of Verambon, and brought
his troupes to a great disorder. This exploit
hath put S
r
Martin in a better conceat in these con-
treis, then any one of his actions heeretofore. And
likewise
e Englishe
y
captaines and companies doe
both give him a singular praise for his conduct and
stratagemes, as also for his cariage and courtesie to
fol.30r
them in particular. In whiche respect, if it might
please yo
r
H. to thanke him in her Ma
ties
name,
and to congratulat his happines, it would be a
meanes to continew his devotion towardes her Hig
nes
.
In
e cause of
Vasseur
there is nothing further
done, since my last to yo
r
H.
Wherw
t
I take
my humble leave. From
e Hage.
Julij 23. 89. Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
Julij 24
I am earnestly solicited by
S
r
Francis Vere
, and
e
other English Captaines, w
t
S
r
Martin Schincke, to move
this Councell of State, that they may returne to their
Garrison, or be imploied neerer home, in
e quarters
about
Bommel:
and to procure w
t
all, that they may
receave better paim
t
, being very muche distressed
through their want of mony, and dearth of all thinges
in those places, where they are in service. I doe not
dout
of obtening
at they may be revoked to serve in these
quarters: but for their paim
t
I can but only recom-
mend their sute to yo
r
H. having sent unto yo
w
, for
e better testimony of their service and desert S
r
Martin
Schinckes letter written unto me. And if by yo
r
H.
procurement they might receave, besides their weekely
Lendinges, some extraordinarie imprest uppn their
paiment, it would be a speciall encouragement both
to them and to others to deserve
e like favo
r
hereaft
r
.
